subject: Re: Ant batchtest vs Test suite for prioritization
msgSnippet: ... Yes, that s right for sure. ... This is true; however, the drawback with too many TestSuites is that you have to recompile any time you touch a single line
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, David Saff <david@...> wrote:
>
> I think that the decision to understand and prioritize your
> tests will make a bigger impact than the method you use to do
> so.

Yes, that's right for sure.

> Myself, I like to gather tests into Java-level suite
> classes, because these can be reused in ant, Eclipse, maven,

This is true; however, the drawback with too many TestSuites
is that you have to recompile any time you touch a single line
of code, vs. just having to modify an external XML file.

> One advantage of ant is that you can fail fast, deciding that
> if suite A fails, don't even bother running suite B. Also,
> sometimes the build system or political structure of a team can
> make it easier to edit XML files than Java, in which case the
> ant file might make sense.

Some details on the environment:

* Rather small project and team (3-4 active developers,
including myself),
* Rather vanilla J2EE web application (Struts-based web gui and
Hibernate+RDBMS backend)
* Rather mature development stage
* All main activities (development, deployment and testing) are
performed entirely with the IDE (Eclipse)
* Currently lacking an automated testing/build environment (i.e.
everything is done manually)

could these be of any help in making a decision (or in finding a
tradeoff)...?

Thanks
Emmanuele
